Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Female settlement patterns and social relationships in chimpanzees, a male-philopatric species
Award.AbstractNarration: As humans? closest living relatives, chimpanzees have great relevance for understanding human behavioral biology. However, because of their long life-span, slow reproductive rate and great social complexity, many fundamental questions about wild chimpanzee biology remain unresolved. This project will support the continued collection of daily behavioral data in three social groups of wild chimpanzees in Gombe National Park, Tanzania, where they have been studied continuously since Jane Goodall began her work in 1960. The overarching goal of this long-term study is to understand the ecological and evolutionary determinants of the behavior of this remarkable species. Like many human societies, male chimpanzees remain for life in their natal group, forming close social bonds with relatives, while females typically emigrate and join new groups at social maturity, even in the face of competition from resident females. A particular goal of this project is to investigate why some females emigrate from their social group, where they settle in their new group?s territory, and how they compete with resident females for food and social status. The answers to these questions will illuminate the evolutionary determinants of competition and cooperation in chimpanzees and other species. The data will be added to a permanent digital database stored at Duke University and accessible over the web. Dissemination of the results of this project in the scientific and popular press, film documentaries, educational videos and widely visited websites will keep these iconic chimpanzees in the public eye worldwide, and will continue to draw young people (including women) into science and foster support for the conservation of this endangered species. The project will involve undergraduates from underrepresented groups, afford employment and education to Tanzanians and provide crucial information that will aid community conservation efforts around Gombe National Park.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chimpanzees provide clues to the origins of human social bonds

Social connectedness powerfully influences human health and longevity, yet the complexities of modern society make it difficult to identify common patterns and root causes underlying differences in social bonding. Investigating the patterns of sociality in our closest living relatives can provide insight.  Chimpanzees, like humans, are very unusual among mammals in that males remain in their birth group and cooperate to defend the group range, while most females join another group at adolescence. In many species, kinship provides a fundamental basis for friendly bonds, but dispersing female chimpanzees must leave their kin and join groups of unrelated individuals, many of which are hostile to these new competitors. Until now, the factors influencing why some females choose to disperse while others stay, how a young female integrates into a new community, and the nature of the social relationships she establishes have remained a mystery for two main reasons. First, chimpanzees have extremely slow life histories – they can live for over 50 years, do not reach sexual maturity until their teens, and reproduce very slowly. Second, habituation and long-term study of multiple, adjacent groups is required. In this project we took advantage of and extended the uniquely long-term study of three social groups of chimpanzees in Gombe National Park, Tanzania, initiated by Jane Goodall in 1960.

We found that adolescent females with close male relatives in their natal community were more likely to emigrate, probably to avoid inbreeding, while those with living, high-ranking mothers were more likely to stay.  The latter maintained life-long, very strong bonds with their mothers.  We also identified strong preferences among unrelated females, suggesting that social bonding is important regardless of the availability of relatives. In particular, the mothers of male juveniles associated together, perhaps for the advantages of socialization for their sons. Also, low-ranking young immigrant females tended to form bonds with each other, which may afford them protection from aggressive resident females and enable them to forage in better areas.

Previous work has shown that female reproductive success depends on a female’s social rank and the quality of her foraging area within the community range. We sought a more complete understanding of the causes of variation in these patterns, including the role of social bonds.  We found that unlike males, who achieve social status by challenging and dominating higher-ranking individuals, a female’s rank only increased as older and higher ranking females died and younger females entered the hierarchy beneath the female.  However, initial entry points varied and females whose mothers were still alive were likely to enter the hierarchy at higher positions than those whose mother was not, suggesting the importance of social support for acquiring status.

To gain an understanding of how females acquired good quality foraging areas, we combined data from vegetation plots with satellite images to create a detailed high-resolution map of the distribution of food sources over the study area. Using long-term behavioral data we found that females foraged in higher quality areas than males, and that those that had been in the social group longer occupied foraging areas that contained more important food items.  As data on young females in this slowly reproducing species continue to accumulate, the foundation is now in place for future research on how a young female’s own rank and social relationships combine with the distribution of food and the density and rank of resident females to determine where she settles and the degree to which her social bonds influence her acquisition of a high quality core ...
